bestBHT.bht: A blind man sat by the wayside begging, most likely between the old and new Jericho. While Mark identifies him as Bartimaeus, there is no mention of his name in Luke's account. It is important to note that this blind man is different from the blind man healed by Jesus as he entered Jericho.

Archibald T. Robertson: Unto Jericho (εις Ιερειχω). See on Matthew 20:29; Mark 10:46, for discussion of the two Jerichos in Mark and Matt. (the old and the new as here)."
Begging (επαιτων). Asking for something. He probably was by the wayside between the old Jericho and the new Roman Jericho."
Mark gives his name Bartimaeus (Luke 10:46). Matthew 20:30 mentions two.
John Gill: a certain blind man sat by the way side begging: this was not blind Bartimaeus, nor his companion, for they were cured by Christ as he went out of Jericho.
but this man before he came to it; for we afterwards read of his entrance into, and passing through Jericho,
though much the same things are related in this account, as in that of the other two blind men

bhtAttempts.bht: A blind man sat by the wayside begging, most likely between the old and new Jericho. While Mark identifies him as Bartimaeus, there is no mention of his name in Luke's account. It is important to note that this blind man is different from the blind man healed by Jesus as he entered Jericho. Although there are similarities in the details described by Matthew and Mark, Luke provides a unique perspective on this encounter.
